name: Flatey - Colorful Summer Island in Breiðafjörður
description: Flatey represents Iceland's most charming stepping-back-in-time island experience, located in Breiðafjörður bay between Snæfellsnes Peninsula and Westfjords where 30 small colorful houses line dusty path through beautifully preserved village hosting just 6 year-round residents who multiply to 50+ during summer months when seasonal residents, hotel guests, artists, and festival visitors transform quiet winter isolation into vibrant cultural hub celebrating Iceland's pre-modern island character. The island's status as Breiðafjörður's largest island (approximately 2 square kilometers) and only year-round inhabited island creates unique position where historical importance, architectural preservation, and seasonal tourism economy coexist without automobiles, paved roads, or modern development that characterizes mainland Iceland—only few tractors serve two active farms maintaining agricultural tradition dating to settlement era. The colorful timber houses dating primarily to 19th and early 20th centuries represent perfectly maintained examples of Scandinavian architectural influence where brightly painted wooden walls, corrugated metal roofs, and compact proportions create photogenic streetscape appearing unchanged since Iceland's Danish colonial period when Flatey served as major cultural and commercial center hosting one of Iceland's earliest libraries (established 1864) that became repository for illuminated manuscripts and literary treasures before collection transferred to Reykjavík.
address: Flatey, Breiðafjörður, Iceland (between Snæfellsnes and Westfjords)
